enamel

Class Player

  • java.lang.Object
    • enamel.Player
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AudioPlayer, VisualPlayer

    public abstract class Player
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides abstract and concrete methods for simulating a braille cell.

    The constructor initializes the window and takes as arguments the number of Braille Cells and the number of buttons the simulator should display. This class also contains several methods that allow for the manipulation of the Player, some implemented and others remain abstract for future implementation.

    Author:
    ENAMEL team: Sunjik Lee, Li Yin, Vassilios Tzerpos.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Player

        public Player(int brailleCellNumber,
              int buttonNumber)
        Constructor for the Player abstract class, used by classes that extend this class. The constructor contains the basic implementation necessary for all Player subclasses, such as checking the validity of brailleCellNumber and buttonNumber (non-negative), as well as creating the specified number of BrailleCell objects and adding it to the brailleList List.
        Parameters:
        brailleCellNumber - the number of braille cells the Player should have
        buttonNumber - the number of buttons the Player should have
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one or both of the two parameters is negative or 0

      • Player

        public Player()

    • Method Detail

      • getCell

        public BrailleCell getCell(int index)
        Returns a reference to the BrailleCell object at the index passed as argument.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the BrailleCell object whose reference is to be returned
        Returns:
        reference to the BrailleCell object at the index passed as argument
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the index is negative or equal to or bigger than brailleCellNumber (the number of Braille Cells initialized)

      • clearAllCells

        public void clearAllCells()
        Clears all the Braille Cells, i.e lowers all the pins for all of them, effectively making them show nothing.

      • displayString

        public void displayString(java.lang.String aString)
                   throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Displays the string passed as argument on all the Braille Cells. If the string is shorter than the total number of Braille Cells, the remaining cells are cleared. However, if the string is longer it only displays the part of it up to however many Braille Cells there are and ignores the rest.
        Parameters:
        aString - the String to be displayed on the BrailleCells
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • refresh

        public abstract void refresh()
        An abstract method to refresh the current implementation's "display" of its BrailleCells, whether the display is audio, visual, or hardware, or other implementations that extend this class.

      • addSkipButtonListener

        public abstract void addSkipButtonListener(int index,
                                           java.lang.String param,
                                           ScenarioParser sp)
        Adds a "Skip Button" for the ScenarioParser's class to continue processing text after the ScenarioParser's userInput is set to true. Changes userInput to false to allow the ScenarioParser to continue.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the button to add the listener to
        param - the String in ScenarioParser to skip to, needed for ScenarioParser's skip(String indicator) method
        sp - the reference to the current ScenarioParser object

      • removeButtonListener

        public abstract void removeButtonListener(int index)
        Removes the Listener on the Button specified by the argument.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the button

        public abstract void addRepeatButtonListener(int index,
                                             ScenarioParser sp)
